{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3151498,"name":"","username":"01101000_01101001","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/0/85e7bf/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-23T21:50:42.217Z","cooked":"

see title. We have SysID set up and reporting the correct distances for forwards, but how are we supposed to run the backwards test when the elevator can’t hold itself up?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-02-23T21:50:42.217Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":63,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":334.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":427876,"topic_slug":"running-backwards-sysid-for-elevator-that-can-t-hold-itself-up","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55942,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Prog Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/running-backwards-sysid-for-elevator-that-can-t-hold-itself-up/427876/1","custom_user_title":"Prog Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3151969,"name":"Joshua Epperson","username":"jepperson","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/74df32/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-24T17:32:39.288Z","cooked":"

You could calculate kS and kV manually by seeing how much voltage you need to move for kS and for kV if your voltage gains were in rps then it’d be how much voltage do you need to apply to go 1 rpm. If that’s not possible for your system due to limit constraints you could also see how much voltage you need to apply to go x angular distance and do the unit conversions to go back to whatever units/s you are using for your feedforward controller

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-02-24T17:32:39.288Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":74.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427876,"topic_slug":"running-backwards-sysid-for-elevator-that-can-t-hold-itself-up","display_username":"Joshua Epperson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/running-backwards-sysid-for-elevator-that-can-t-hold-itself-up/427876/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3151997,"name":"","username":"01101000_01101001","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/0/85e7bf/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-24T18:16:41.736Z","cooked":"

This is the solution we have settled on (for now)

Step 1: Run a static test
Step 1a: Increase voltage until the elevator begins to rise
Step 1b: Record voltage (let’s say kG_a)
Step 1c: Decrease voltage until the elevator begins to fall
Step 1d: Record voltage (let’s say kG_b)
Step 2: Calculate kG by taking the average of the two voltages ([kG_a+kG_b]/2)
Step 3: Calculate kS by taking half of the distance between kG_b and kG_a (abs(kG_a-kG_b)/2)
Step 4: Run our fork of sysid that has the backward tests removed, this will give us kV and kA

Thanks to @Oblarg for suggesting the static test routine as well as suggesting to combine the two methods to produce the best results

Thanks to @calcmogul for letting me know that the backward tests can be omitted with only slight effects (kS from sysid will be slightly less accurate without backward tests).
